lcInstruction.p: The basic elements involved in creating a set of steps include the <steps>, <step>, <cmd>, and <info> elements.

stentry.p: The container element for a series of step-by-step instructions.
The container element for each step in the <steps> element. The <steps> element can contain one or more <step> elements.
The container element for the command, or text instructing the user what to do, in a <step> element. Each <step> element can contain exactly one <cmd> element.

The container element for additional information about a step. The <info> element must go inside the <step> element after the <cmd> element. Each <step> element can contain one or more <info> elements (or none at all, as the <info> element is optional).

step.cmd: Continue working in the file l_task_start.dita.

info.xref: Video: Adding steps to a DITA task

step.cmd: After the closing tag of the <context> element, add a <steps> element.

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE task PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Task//EN" "task.dtd"> <task id="my_first_task"> ... </context> <steps> </steps> </taskbody> </task>

info.p: As with the <prereq> and <context> elements, the <taskbody> can contain only one <steps> element. Restricting you to a single <steps> element helps ensure that the topic only describes how to perform one task.

step.cmd: Inside the <steps> element, add a <step> element.

info.p: The <steps> element must contain at least one <step> element. Most DITA-aware editors automatically add a first <step> element inside the <steps> element.

stepsection.p: In DITA, the content of each individual step is also highly controlled; each step has a specific set of elements, which must occur in a specific order. The action the user is to perform is contained in a <cmd> element (read as “command”), which is a required element in <step>. In most cases, <cmd> contains a single sentence, which is a direct instruction to the reader to perform an action.

step.cmd: Inside the <step> element, add a <cmd> element with the text shown here.

info.p: As a best practice, the <cmd> element should be limited to a single sentence, in active voice, that directs the user to perform an action. To provide additional information about the <cmd> element, use the <info> element (discussed in the next step).
Because <step> must contain exactly one <cmd> element, most DITA-aware editors add the <cmd> element when they add the <step> element.

steps.stepsection: To provide additional information about the step direction contained in the <cmd> element, use the <info> element. You can use any number of <info> elements after the <cmd> element, and before the <stepresult> element.

step.cmd: After the <cmd> element, add an <info> element, with the text shown here.

stepxmp.pre:
... Choose a location to watch ducks.

Generally, ducks are found in wild locations, near water.

 ...

info.p:
The element can contain text, notes, images, tables and so on. As with other elements that can contain mixed content, best practices dictate that you should use a

element to wrap text, even if the element only contains one paragraph.
The remaining topics in this lesson introduce additional elements you can use to further document the step.
